slides.ocrText: Configuring Permissions

Lesson
objectives

* Create system permissions

¢ Write Gosu expressions that evaluate user
permissions

¢ Use application permission keys

Permissions, Roles, and Access Control
Lists

slides.originalNotes:
Permissions
When an end user attempts to login to an application, the following occurs:

The user supplies their user name and password to ClaimCenter via the login page.
ClaimCenter authenticates the user and determines which permissions are assigned to the user and the user's start page. Permissions determine which screens the user can navigate to, and which actions the user can perform. The startup view is the first page rendered after log im
ClaimCenter authenticates the user:
In the base configuration, authentication is managed through the ClaimCenter database 
There is a table in the database which stores user names and passwords.
The system can be configured to authenticate against an existing user domain structure.
ClaimCenter renders the appropriate startup view with permissions appropriate for that user.
A users permissions are determined at login. However, if an administrator changes a user’s permissions while that user is logged in, the new permissions are applied immediately.
slides.notes:
Permissions
When an end user attempts to login to an application, the following occurs:

The user supplies their user name and password to ClaimCenter via the login page.
ClaimCenter authenticates the user and determines which permissions are assigned to the user and the user's start page. Permissions determine which screens the user can navigate to, and which actions the user can perform. The startup view is the first page rendered after log im
ClaimCenter authenticates the user:
In the base configuration, authentication is managed through the ClaimCenter database 
There is a table in the database which stores user names and passwords.
The system can be configured to authenticate against an existing user domain structure.
ClaimCenter renders the appropriate startup view with permissions appropriate for that user.
A users permissions are determined at login. However, if an administrator changes a user’s permissions while that user is logged in, the new permissions are applied immediately.
slides.ocrText:
| Permissions

¢ Apermission allows a user to do one of the following:
* View or navigate to an object
* Create, edit, or delete an object
* Own an object
* Act on an object

¢ For purposes of permissions, “an object’ is either:
« A database object such as a claim or an activity, or
« Auser interface (Ul) component such as a location or a button

¢ Permissions are defined by the
SystemPermissionType typelist

* You can add custom permissions to this list

¢ Are not assigned directly to users

slides.originalNotes:
Roles
Each user has one or more roles assigned to them. Each role defines a set of permissions allowing the user to do certain things within an applicatiom What a user can do in the application is the combination of all of the user's permissions and roles.
slides.notes:
Roles
Each user has one or more roles assigned to them. Each role defines a set of permissions allowing the user to do certain things within an applicatiom What a user can do in the application is the combination of all of the user's permissions and roles.
slides.ocrText:
| Roles Gi

¢ Are named collections of permissions that define a job’s tasks
* Arole typically maps to a job title or function
¢ Are assigned directly to individual users

slides.originalNotes:
Two ways of organizing tasks into roles
You can organize tasks into roles in whatever manner you choose. Two common strategies are shown in the diagram.

On the left, each role is isolated" and contains all of the permissions needed for a given user. In this strategy, the same permissions may exist in many roles, and each user is assigned to only one role.
On the right, each role has a unique set of permissions. To assign a user more permissions, they must be assigned more roles. For example, the Adjuster has all the permissions of the Service Rep, and is assigned the  Service Rep role plus an Adjuster role which includes only the additional permissions needed by the Adjuster.
slides.notes:
Two ways of organizing tasks into roles
You can organize tasks into roles in whatever manner you choose. Two common strategies are shown in the diagram.

On the left, each role is isolated" and contains all of the permissions needed for a given user. In this strategy, the same permissions may exist in many roles, and each user is assigned to only one role.
On the right, each role has a unique set of permissions. To assign a user more permissions, they must be assigned more roles. For example, the Adjuster has all the permissions of the Service Rep, and is assigned the  Service Rep role plus an Adjuster role which includes only the additional permissions needed by the Adjuster.

slides.originalNotes:
Access control lists (ACLs)
To clarify, each claim has a unique Access Control List, which lists the users with access to the claim. In the example, Ida Belt (service representative), Andy Applegate (adjuster), and Sue Smith (claims supervisor) are on the claim's access control list 

The Access Control List is an Array from the Claim table to the ClaimAccess table. Each ClaimAccess entity contains a foreign key to a group, user, or security zone which has access to the Claim. There is also a Boolean column called "Anyone".  If this column is set to true, then any user has access to the claim;  however, this is rarely implemented.
slides.notes:
Access control lists (ACLs)
To clarify, each claim has a unique Access Control List, which lists the users with access to the claim. In the example, Ida Belt (service representative), Andy Applegate (adjuster), and Sue Smith (claims supervisor) are on the claim's access control list 

The Access Control List is an Array from the Claim table to the ClaimAccess table. Each ClaimAccess entity contains a foreign key to a group, user, or security zone which has access to the Claim. There is also a Boolean column called "Anyone".  If this column is set to true, then any user has access to the claim;  however, this is rarely implemented.
slides.ocrText:
| Access control lists (ACLs)

¢ Are lists associated with claims
¢ Identify the users who may access the claim

¢ Ensure that only users with a “need” can view or edit a claim

slides.originalNotes:
Permissions and ACLs
In order to view or act on a claim, a user must have the appropriate permission as well as appear on the claim's ACL. In the example above:
Jason Tran (adjuster) has the View Claim permission, but he is not listed on the ACL for Claim #100-00-100001. Therefore, he cannot view claim.
Andy Applegate (adjuster) has the View Claim permission and is allowed to view claims on the ACL for Claim #100-00- 100001
Jim Nozick (user administrator) is listed on the ACL for Claim #100-00- 100001 as someone who can view the claim. However, he does not have the view claim system permissiom Therefore, he cannot view claim 100-00- 100001

slides.originalNotes:
Application permission keys (APKs)
An Application Permission Key (APK) is defined by the system as a collection of permissions and associated functionality.  APKs are defined in the code that defines core objects. They are defined to optimize the evaluation of permissions and are more eficient than simple permissions. It is easy to tell a permission from an APK. Permissions begin with •perm.System," while APKs begin •perm. entitV.
slides.notes:
Application permission keys (APKs)
An Application Permission Key (APK) is defined by the system as a collection of permissions and associated functionality.  APKs are defined in the code that defines core objects. They are defined to optimize the evaluation of permissions and are more eficient than simple permissions. It is easy to tell a permission from an APK. Permissions begin with •perm.System," while APKs begin •perm. entitV.
slides.ocrText:
| Application permission keys (APKs) fa

« An application permission key (APK) is a system-defined group of SS
one or more permissions plus additional logic SS

* Groups permissions according to entities and business processes
¢ Every APK is associated with a single entity Claim Edit
* Cannot be created or modified
¢ Appears in the files used to specify the user interface

slides.originalNotes:
Static and object-based permissions
A permission or APK may be either static or object-based. Object-based permissions reference the object's ACL. Users must have both the permission and membership in the ACL in order to perform these actions, which are typically used for objects that require some additional level of security. Static permissions do not reference the object's ACL, and can be used •across the board".
slides.notes:
Static and object-based permissions
A permission or APK may be either static or object-based. Object-based permissions reference the object's ACL. Users must have both the permission and membership in the ACL in order to perform these actions, which are typically used for objects that require some additional level of security. Static permissions do not reference the object's ACL, and can be used •across the board".
slides.ocrText:
| Static and object-based permissions

¢ Static permissions are granted or
denied across the entire application

* Object-based permissions are
granted or denied on a claim-by-claim
basis

* These permissions are ACL related

Question

,- — Whatis the difference between a permission and an application

Pa permission key (APK) containing only one permission?
¢

SS eee eee ee Soo e Sse

Answer Gi

,— — Whatis the difference between a permission and an application

Pa permission key (APK) containing only one permission?
¢

Possible answers:
* Apermission can be created by a Guidewire configurator, while an APK cannot.
* Apermission can be added to a role, while an APK cannot.

* Apermissions check using an APK will execute faster than a permissions check
which directly references a permission.

_— — Whatis the difference between an APK with two permissions (such as
: “create note” and “edit note”) and a role with the same two pernissions?

¢
¢

Possible answers:

An APK is created to optimize permissions checks. A role is created to assign
permissions to users.

Developers can create and modify roles. Developers cannot create or modify APKs.

Security Dictionary

slides.originalNotes:
Review: Security dictionary
The security dictionary is located at: <server urity\index.html. The security dictionary reflects the initial relationship between permissions and roles, and lists four types of information:
Application permission keys
Pages (in the user interface)
System Permissions
Roles
System permissions are assigned to roles to grant those roles specific behaviors and permissions. Roles are then assigned to users- Once a user is assigned a role, that user has all of the permissions that were assigned to the role.
ClaimCenter defines application permission keys internally as a method for improving system performance. For example, the claimedit permission key represents the system permissions for editing a claim. 
claimedit for open claims 
claimeditclsd for closed claims.
Application permission keys are generally used to control access to user interface elements. A screen or button may be restricted by an application permission key-The Application Permission
Keys section of the security dictionary lists each  application permission key, the set of system permissions it contains, and the pages and elements in the user interface that reference the application permission key-

Security dictionary: APKs
As previously mentioned, an APK is a collection of permissions. The security dictionary APKs page provides a menu of all existing APKs, and lists the permissions
for each APK. It also tells whether the permission is static or object based. The first image shows the permissions for Activity assign,  an object-based APK; the second shows AuthorityLimit create, a static APK.

slides.originalNotes:
Security dictionary: Pages
Every page in the application has a canVisit expression which determines who can view the page, and a canEdit expression which determines who can edit the page. The security dictionary Pages provides a menu of all existing Pages, and displays their canVisit and canEdit expressions for each Page. The menu also lists Forwards, which have a canVisit expression, and displays the canVisit expression for both canVisit and canEdit. In addition,  it also lists Screens and Views,  which have neither expression.  The screenshot shows the canVisit and canEdit expressions for the Account Detail page.
slides.notes:

slides.originalNotes:
Security dictionary: System permissions
The security dictionary System Permissions page provides a menu of all existing system permissions. For each permission, it lists:
The roles to which this permission has been assigned, either directly or through an APK; Any APKs which include this permission
Any pages which use this permission in their canView or canEdit expressions, either directly or through an APK; and
Any elements in a page or screen which uses this permission, either directly or through an APK.
The screenshot shows the claimown permission, although the Roles section has been cut off, most of the information is clear. The Related Elements shows that claimown is used in the visible attribute of an input set in the UserStatistics detail view.

7
¢
¢

SS eee eee ee Soo e Sse

Answer Gi

,— — How can you generate or update the security dictionary?
y ¢
“ The correct answers are using one of these two ways:
1. Atthe command line, navigate to the ClaimCenter root directory and enter gwb
genDataDictionary. The security dictionary is generated along with the data
dictionary.

2. On the Export Data page of the Administration tab, you may choose to generate
the security dictionary either as HTML or as XML. In either case, the file is then
downloaded as a .ZIP.

Configuring Permissions

slides.originalNotes:
SystemPermissionType typelist
You can add static permissions to the system by defining them on the SystemPermissionType typelist. They are added as you would to any typelist, then use in the permission expressions. You cannot create new object-based permissions.
slides.notes:
SystemPermissionType typelist
You can add static permissions to the system by defining them on the SystemPermissionType typelist. They are added as you would to any typelist, then use in the permission expressions. You cannot create new object-based permissions.

APKs are added in the same manner as permissions, with the addition that for object-based keys, you must include a reference to the object whose ACL is being used, as if the APK were a function of the object’s entity type.
